GT.content: temporalization of time (memory, anticipation, pro, re- tention) destroys the gift
GT.linkedContent: temporalization of time (memory, anticipation, pro, re- tention) destroys the gift

GT.content: Husserl’s donating intuition (gebende Anschauung): principle of principles

OOG.content: axiomatics (from which alone every ideal of exhaustive and exact deductivity can take its sense) presuppose a sedimentation of sense, a radical ground (primordial evidence) which is already past, thus axiomatics exiled by Husserl from the origins to which he wants to return
OOG.linkedContent: axiomatics (from which alone every ideal of exhaustive and exact deductivity can take its sense) presuppose a sedimentation of sense, a radical ground (primordial evidence) which is already past, thus axiomatics exiled by Husserl from the origins to which he wants to return

OOG.content: what must be called the dialectic of protention and retention despite Husserl’s repugnance for that word
OOG.linkedContent: what must be called the dialectic of protention and retention despite Husserl’s repugnance for that word

OOG.content: for Husserl, sense precedes act of language, whose value will always be expression
OOG.linkedContent: for Husserl, sense precedes act of language, whose value will always be expression

OOG.content: for Husserl, “objects of the understanding” are preconstituted in predicative spontaneity, “timeless,” are on a “higher level” than “objects of receptivity” (contingent, flesh & blood lion)
OOG.linkedContent: for Husserl, “objects of the understanding” are preconstituted in predicative spontaneity, “timeless,” are on a “higher level” than “objects of receptivity” (contingent, flesh & blood lion)

OOG.content: for Husserl, genuine objectivity is ideal identity beyond contingent validity [?]: “the automobile is the fastest means of travel” loses its validity w/out losing its omnitemporal ideality
OOG.linkedContent: for Husserl, genuine objectivity is ideal identity beyond contingent validity [?]: “the automobile is the fastest means of travel” loses its validity w/out losing its omnitemporal ideality

OOG.content: the way an outdated proposition remains unified & animated by intention of truth, authenticity, clarity (synonyms for Husserl) > absurd intention, “nonsense,” “countersense” continually points toward telos, owns up to telos in order to disown it (Stranger of Sophist)
OOG.linkedContent: the way an outdated proposition remains unified & animated by intention of truth, authenticity, clarity (synonyms for Husserl) > absurd intention, “nonsense,” “countersense” continually points toward telos, owns up to telos in order to disown it (Stranger of Sophist)

OOG.content: Derrida reversing Husserl, “are not no-communication and misunderstanding the very horizon of culture and language?”
OOG.linkedContent: Derrida reversing Husserl, “are not no-communication and misunderstanding the very horizon of culture and language?”

OOG.content: for Husserl, all factual writings in which truth could be sedimented nothing but sensible “exemplars,” they could all be destroyed w/out overtaking the very sense of absolute ideality
OOG.linkedContent: for Husserl, all factual writings in which truth could be sedimented nothing but sensible “exemplars,” they could all be destroyed w/out overtaking the very sense of absolute ideality

OOG.content: w/ sedimented sense, first danger is passivity [for more of Husserl on passivity follow footnotes at bottom of page (p. 99n)]
OOG.linkedContent: w/ sedimented sense, first danger is passivity [for more of Husserl on passivity follow footnotes at bottom of page (p. 99n)]

OOG.content: Husserl & Joyce: two ways to achieve Hegelian endeavor to interiorize memory of culture
OOG.linkedContent: Husserl & Joyce: two ways to achieve Hegelian endeavor to interiorize memory of culture

OOG.content: for Husserl, pure geometry [exact ideality p. 133] prior to imagination and sensibility, Cartesian intellectualism
OOG.linkedContent: for Husserl, pure geometry [exact ideality p. 133] prior to imagination and sensibility, Cartesian intellectualism

OOG.content: Husserl closer to Descartes than Kant here > since Kant no longer derives sensibility from a “sensualist” definition, he argues that geometry is not imaginary because grounded in pure sensibility; for Husserl, geometry is not imaginary because uprooted from all sensible ground
OOG.linkedContent: Husserl closer to Descartes than Kant here > since Kant no longer derives sensibility from a “sensualist” definition, he argues that geometry is not imaginary because grounded in pure sensibility; for Husserl, geometry is not imaginary because uprooted from all sensible ground

OOG.content: in criticizing psychologism & in “the return to the things themselves,” “Husserl urged getting rid of the spectrum of the soul’s faculties and all the vestiges of classic substantialisms”
OOG.linkedContent: in criticizing psychologism & in “the return to the things themselves,” “Husserl urged getting rid of the spectrum of the soul’s faculties and all the vestiges of classic substantialisms”

POOF.content: whole story of eidos, incl. Husserlian interp. of production of ideal objects (idealization), intemporality qua omnitemporality > [but] “takes time to do w/out time”
POOF.linkedContent: whole story of eidos, incl. Husserlian interp. of production of ideal objects (idealization), intemporality qua omnitemporality > [but] “takes time to do w/out time”

EM.content: Husserl not an anthropologist; Husserl worried something like Sein und Zeit would be anthropological
EM.linkedContent: Husserl not an anthropologist; Husserl worried something like Sein und Zeit would be anthropological

EM.content: for Hegel, Husserl, reason is history, and there is no history but of reason
EM.linkedContent: for Hegel, Husserl, reason is history, and there is no history but of reason

EM.content: critique of empirical anthropologism affirmation of transcendental humanism (Husserl, Kant)

SEC.content: Husserl on possibility of absence of referent: 1) “sky is blue” is understood w/ out presence of sky 2) absence of signified, possible crisis of meaning: a) manipulate symbols b) statements can have meaning w/out objective signification, i.e. “square circle” c) Sinnlosigkeit or agrammaticality, i.e. “green is or,” “abracadabra”
SEC.linkedContent: Husserl on possibility of absence of referent: 1) “sky is blue” is understood w/ out presence of sky 2) absence of signified, possible crisis of meaning: a) manipulate symbols b) statements can have meaning w/out objective signification, i.e. “square circle” c) Sinnlosigkeit or agrammaticality, i.e. “green is or,” “abracadabra”

SEC.content: Husserl uses above to rigorously dissociate sign or expression (Ausdruck) as signifying sign from a sign meaning something (bedeutsame Zeichen)
SEC.linkedContent: Husserl uses above to rigorously dissociate sign or expression (Ausdruck) as signifying sign from a sign meaning something (bedeutsame Zeichen)

SEC.content: Husserl’s interest is in purely logical grammar not pure grammar > “the green is or,” unacceptable in context determined by a will to know, still signifies an example of agrammaticality
SEC.linkedContent: Husserl’s interest is in purely logical grammar not pure grammar > “the green is or,” unacceptable in context determined by a will to know, still signifies an example of agrammaticality

SEC.content: in French “le vert est ou” can become “le vert est où” or “le verre est où”
SEC.linkedContent: in French “le vert est ou” can become “le vert est où” or “le verre est où”

VM.content: appeal to tradition found in Husserl’s phenomenology and Heidegger’s “ontology”: 1) entirety of philosophy has a Greek source 2) a reduction of metaphysics 3) the ethical loses its metaphysical specificity, coordinated with something other than itself
VM.linkedContent: appeal to tradition found in Husserl’s phenomenology and Heidegger’s “ontology”: 1) entirety of philosophy has a Greek source 2) a reduction of metaphysics 3) the ethical loses its metaphysical specificity, coordinated with something other than itself

VM.content: that we are consigned to Greek element, a knowledge and confidence that is not comfortable, that torments us > Husserl’s crisis, a covering up of a transcendental motif beginning to accomplish Greek aim in Descartes & Kant: philosophy as science
VM.linkedContent: that we are consigned to Greek element, a knowledge and confidence that is not comfortable, that torments us > Husserl’s crisis, a covering up of a transcendental motif beginning to accomplish Greek aim in Descartes & Kant: philosophy as science

VM.content: for Husserl, one cannot maintain primacy of objectifying act and irreducible originality of nontheoretical consciousness at same time
VM.linkedContent: for Husserl, one cannot maintain primacy of objectifying act and irreducible originality of nontheoretical consciousness at same time

VM.content: Heidegger, according to Levinas, adds historicity to Husserl
VM.linkedContent: Heidegger, according to Levinas, adds historicity to Husserl

VM.content: wasn’t it Husserl who showed us that vision, perception were inadequate, the infinite overflowing of horizons? did he really reduce this inadequation to condition of available objects?
VM.linkedContent: wasn’t it Husserl who showed us that vision, perception were inadequate, the infinite overflowing of horizons? did he really reduce this inadequation to condition of available objects?

VM.content: passivity & activity of Husserl’s “constitution” > not opposed to the encounter; if one rejects his definition, there must be a time/experience w/out “other” before the encounter
VM.linkedContent: passivity & activity of Husserl’s “constitution” > not opposed to the encounter; if one rejects his definition, there must be a time/experience w/out “other” before the encounter

VM.content: Husserl’s alter-ego, nonviolent respect of secret, of separation, we can only know the other through analogical appresentation > translates recognition of radical separation
VM.linkedContent: Husserl’s alter-ego, nonviolent respect of secret, of separation, we can only know the other through analogical appresentation > translates recognition of radical separation

VM.content: eidos as noema in understanding or logos of the infinite subject (God) > how does transcendental idealism escape horizon of infinite subjectivity?
VM.linkedContent: eidos as noema in understanding or logos of the infinite subject (God) > how does transcendental idealism escape horizon of infinite subjectivity?

VM.content: Husserl would say that Plato’s eidos realized outside noema, outside being thought
VM.linkedContent: Husserl would say that Plato’s eidos realized outside noema, outside being thought

OH.content: for Husserl, the European philosopher committed to universal reason is functionary of mankind
OH.linkedContent: for Husserl, the European philosopher committed to universal reason is functionary of mankind

VP.content: Husserl insists on the absence of all presuppositions (Voraussetzungslosigkeit) whether metaphysical, psychological or from natural sciences: does this not all still dissimulate a metaphysical presupposition?
VP.linkedContent: Husserl insists on the absence of all presuppositions (Voraussetzungslosigkeit) whether metaphysical, psychological or from natural sciences: does this not all still dissimulate a metaphysical presupposition?

VP.content: starting point in “Fatkum” of language not a presupposition so long as we’re attentive to contingency of example
VP.linkedContent: starting point in “Fatkum” of language not a presupposition so long as we’re attentive to contingency of example

VP.content: Husserl never posed the question of the transcendental logos, of the inherited language by which phenomenology produces/exhibits itself [logos is logicity first]
VP.linkedContent: Husserl never posed the question of the transcendental logos, of the inherited language by which phenomenology produces/exhibits itself [logos is logicity first]

VP.content: [does Husserl separate mundane life from transcendental life more severely than Heidegger’s ontic/ontological separation?]
VP.linkedContent: [does Husserl separate mundane life from transcendental life more severely than Heidegger’s ontic/ontological separation?]

VP.content: Husserl neutralizes totality of world to phenomenon through transcendental reduction, thus arises the nothing that distinguishes parallels [trans. psychology from trans. phenom.]
VP.linkedContent: Husserl neutralizes totality of world to phenomenon through transcendental reduction, thus arises the nothing that distinguishes parallels [trans. psychology from trans. phenom.]

VP.content: for Husserl, transcendental consciousness not impaired by destruction of this world, we can think consciousness w/out body, w/out soul > can’t substantialize, endow w/ reality
VP.linkedContent: for Husserl, transcendental consciousness not impaired by destruction of this world, we can think consciousness w/out body, w/out soul > can’t substantialize, endow w/ reality

VP.content: Husserl re-secures possibility and rigor of philosophy by reading difference btwn “pure psychology of consciousness” and “transcendental phenomenology of consciousness” through parallelism [?] [compare to parallelism via concept of life in transcendental psychologism on p. 11]
VP.linkedContent: Husserl re-secures possibility and rigor of philosophy by reading difference btwn “pure psychology of consciousness” and “transcendental phenomenology of consciousness” through parallelism [?] [compare to parallelism via concept of life in transcendental psychologism on p. 11]

VP.content: how Saussure makes a quasi-Husserlian move when declaring that the expressive value of “signifier” only happens in its “acoustic image” > sound as prior to phoneme
VP.linkedContent: how Saussure makes a quasi-Husserlian move when declaring that the expressive value of “signifier” only happens in its “acoustic image” > sound as prior to phoneme

VP.content: for Husserl, imagination neutralizes memory, it is a non-“positing” representation, keeps w/in itself primary reference to an originary presentation; pure ideality to which neutralization provides access is not fictional, thus Husserl’s beef w/ Hume and his fascination w/ Hume
VP.linkedContent: for Husserl, imagination neutralizes memory, it is a non-“positing” representation, keeps w/in itself primary reference to an originary presentation; pure ideality to which neutralization provides access is not fictional, thus Husserl’s beef w/ Hume and his fascination w/ Hume

VP.content: Husserl and Freud both view unconscious as “after-the-fact,” Freud’s Nachträglichkeit (après-coup), though Husserl utterly rejects its possibility
VP.linkedContent: Husserl and Freud both view unconscious as “after-the-fact,” Freud’s Nachträglichkeit (après-coup), though Husserl utterly rejects its possibility

VP.content: for Husserl, “S is P” is original apophantic operation, the fundamental, primitive form
VP.linkedContent: for Husserl, “S is P” is original apophantic operation, the fundamental, primitive form

VP.content: Husserl tormented by possibility that writing inhabits inside of speech, itself at work in intimacy of thought
VP.linkedContent: Husserl tormented by possibility that writing inhabits inside of speech, itself at work in intimacy of thought

S.content: Husserl shows signs of the worst w/ his racism against Eskimos, Papuans, Indians [spirit not an accidental ornament for Husserl’s thought]
S.linkedContent: Husserl shows signs of the worst w/ his racism against Eskimos, Papuans, Indians [spirit not an accidental ornament for Husserl’s thought]

S.content: acc. Heidegger, Descartes, Husserl, both dogmatic, their concepts not ontologically clarified via Being
S.linkedContent: acc. Heidegger, Descartes, Husserl, both dogmatic, their concepts not ontologically clarified via Being

POS.content: juridically decisive for Derrida to pose question of privilege of voice in Western metaphysics, represented in its most critical, vigilant form: Husserl’s transcendental phenomenology
POS.linkedContent: juridically decisive for Derrida to pose question of privilege of voice in Western metaphysics, represented in its most critical, vigilant form: Husserl’s transcendental phenomenology

GSP.content: how “untamed genesis” demanded of Husserl a metaphysics of history and a solid structure of telos, moving phenomenology beyond descriptive space, beyond phenomenology?
GSP.linkedContent: how “untamed genesis” demanded of Husserl a metaphysics of history and a solid structure of telos, moving phenomenology beyond descriptive space, beyond phenomenology?

GSP.content: Derrida gives an account of how Husserl navigated Scylla and Charybdis of logicizing structuralism and psychologistic genetism re: mathematical/logical synthesis
GSP.linkedContent: Derrida gives an account of how Husserl navigated Scylla and Charybdis of logicizing structuralism and psychologistic genetism re: mathematical/logical synthesis

GSP.content: Husserl: no continuity btwn psychological development and logical unity
GSP.linkedContent: Husserl: no continuity btwn psychological development and logical unity

GSP.content: Husserl always announcing/deferring a new “transcendental aesthetic”

FS.content: in Origin of Geo… Husserl teaches us: meaning must await being said or written to inhabit itself, it becomes by differing from itself: this is meaning (writing does not await prescription from some topos ouranios, or divine understanding)
FS.linkedContent: in Origin of Geo… Husserl teaches us: meaning must await being said or written to inhabit itself, it becomes by differing from itself: this is meaning (writing does not await prescription from some topos ouranios, or divine understanding)

FS.content: like structuralism, no concept of force in Husserl (brings phenomenology back to Platonism despite professed anti-Platonism); for Husserl, truth requires forgetting [of genesis, force, failure, crises]
FS.linkedContent: like structuralism, no concept of force in Husserl (brings phenomenology back to Platonism despite professed anti-Platonism); for Husserl, truth requires forgetting [of genesis, force, failure, crises]

CHM.content: Cogito as fugitive [cf. furtive in PS], ungraspable, escapes linear order, determinations of  natural light > repeats itself in Husserlian Cogito [though Husserl had to reduce it to affirm madness of his reduction]
CHM.linkedContent: Cogito as fugitive [cf. furtive in PS], ungraspable, escapes linear order, determinations of natural light > repeats itself in Husserlian Cogito [though Husserl had to reduce it to affirm madness of his reduction]

TN.content: feeling oneself feel is not corporeal but spiritual for Husserl & Descartes
TN.linkedContent: feeling oneself feel is not corporeal but spiritual for Husserl & Descartes

TN.content: [Husserl utilizes a Hegel-like mediate immediacy re: touch]

TN.linkedContent: [Husserl on what happens when I touch another’s hand]

TN.content: Husserl wants to be more Cartesian than Descartes
TN.linkedContent: Husserl wants to be more Cartesian than Descartes

TN.content: Derrida defends Husserl’s stubborn conviction that we can’t know alter-ego, only through analogy, appresentation, that there’s an unbridgeable abyss (abîme infranchissable) > Husserl’s stance prevents risk of an immediate intutionism of the other

TN.linkedContent: Husserl never solved the riddle of Einfühling (empathy)

BSi.content: Husserl’s free ideality (i.e. the number “two” repeated identically) vs. bound (gebundene) idealities (ideal only in body)
BSi.linkedContent: Husserl’s free ideality (i.e. the number “two” repeated identically) vs. bound (gebundene) idealities (ideal only in body)

OG.content: in Husserl’s changing premises of debate,” neither natural inside nor outside > must distinguish le son apparasissant from l’apparaître du son > always divided w/in themselves btwn variance and invariability, an unheard difference, invisible > trace opens appearance
OG.linkedContent: in Husserl’s changing premises of debate,” neither natural inside nor outside > must distinguish le son apparasissant from l’apparaître du son > always divided w/in themselves btwn variance and invariability, an unheard difference, invisible > trace opens appearance

CIR.content: nervous, worried, hunted, literature (beast playing dead, melding w/ foliage), delivering to world impregnable inedible simulacrum, the theory of the parasite virus, terrorizing others w/ instability he carries everywhere, one book open in the other
CIR.linkedContent: nervous, worried, hunted, literature (beast playing dead, melding w/ foliage), delivering to world impregnable inedible simulacrum, the theory of the parasite virus, terrorizing others w/ instability he carries everywhere, one book open in the other
